newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Samsung Motors says not interested in Kia takeover.
newsitem.headline: Samsung Motors says not interested in Kia takeover.

text.p: South Korea's Samsung Motors said on Saturday it was not interested in taking over Kia Motors, the flagship of the troubed Kia Group.
"We have no plan to take over Kia Motors and are not interested," said a Samsung spokesman. "We hope Kia will recover from the current hardship."

Samsung also said it demanded the existing companies should apologise for their accusation that Samsung "deliberately" leaked an internal memo suggesting restructuring of the nation's car industry and alleging "managerial conflicts" at Kia.
"We want to restore our damaged reputation," he said.
"We may have to take legal actions without acceptable apology," the spokesman said.
In June, Hyundai Motor Co and five other South Korean automakers said they would take joint action against Samsung over the report.
The Kia Group then filed complaint against Samsung to prosecutors. But almost crippled by financial troubles, Kia dropped the complaint earlier this week.
Kia Motors was battered by slow domestic sales and strong competition from Daewoo Motors and Kia Steel faced cash shortages after heavy capital investment.
Samsung was rumoured to be interested in buying Kia as a short-cut into the industry's top ranks.
Analysts said Samsung was considered the most likely group to take over Kia because of its own automaking aspirations and its financial resources.

In 1994 Samsung won a government license to enter the car industry in a technical tie-up with Nissan Motor Co. Samsung plans to make 80,000 vehicles in 1998, with the output rising to 250,000 in 1999 and 500,000 by 2002.
